newsitem.title: GERMANY: Passive German cocoa buyers target lower prices.
newsitem.headline: Passive German cocoa buyers target lower prices.

text.p: German cash cocoa buyers are looking for lower prices before committing themselves to raw materials purchases, traders said on Thursday.
Markets would stay lifeless as long as futures remained range-bound and sterling at historically high levels.

"It's no secret that multinational firms have good long term cover while small and medium sized companies in Europe need to buy more spot beans," one said. "But flat futures markets won't offer the necessary inspiration and chocolate sales are depressing."
Traders said cocoa could potentially benefit from sympathy with rallying coffee prices or specific fund interest.

The industry would welcome bullish factors because it would like to present consumers with plausible reasons to raise chocolate prices -- as had been possible in coffee -- to improve its weak margins.
June bean price offers for West African cif material were pegged at 2.80 marks, up from 2.77 marks last week, with buyers' ideas at 2.60-2.65.
June cocoa butter cost 6.96 marks per kg liquid, ex-works, on the basis of a 2.43 butter ratio over futures.
Spot butter buyers' ideas were pegged at 6.65 marks.
West African third quarter beans were quoted at 2.84 marks (2.79 previously).
The cocoa butter ratio was at 2.43 (2.44) for the third and at 2.50 (2.51) for the fourth quarter, with mark prices at 7.02 (7.01) and 7.10 (7.08) respectively.
